Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile Santiago 7820436 Chile Molybdenum carbide catalysts supported on monoclinic and tetragonal zirconium oxide were studied for hydrogen production through aqueous phase reforming of ethanol. Catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, XRD, TPR and XPS. Results showed that 10%Mo2C/m-ZrO2 was less carburized and had a lower surface area than 10%Mo2C/t-ZrO2 and 10%MoC/t-ZrO2. Mo oxide was identified on the surface as well as two types of Mo oxycarbide and Mo oxynitride. The α crystalline phase of the carbide was more active than β phase and was ascribed to its higher relative superficial distribution. However, the α phase generated less H2 probably because there was less oxycarbide presence. 10%Mo2C/m-ZrO2 produced significantly more H2 and was stable for five consecutive reactions. This catalyst showed higher carburization degree after the reaction, which greatly enhanced the generation of H2, suggesting that carbides species improved H2 production compared to oxycarbides. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Molybdenum carbide Aqueous phase reforming Hydrogen production Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nowadays, most goods and services rely on fossil fuels for manufacturing and transportation. Petroleum is the main energy source worldwide and a major driver of the world’s economy. However, crude oil is highly damaging to the environment, making the search for sustainable alternatives mandatory. Hydrogen is a versatile energy transporter [1] and has the highest energy content per unit mass among traditional fuels [2]. Its uses range from industrial areas to transport applications, but it is generally produced from carbon and natural gas, generating carbon dioxide emissions [3]. Thus, an opportunity arises to find new ways to produce hydrogen from renewable sources. Biomass has received great attention for its potential as an energy source [4]. Lignocellulosic biomass is the most abundant type of biomass around the world, and its three main components are cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin. Depending on biomass origin, cellulose represents 35–50%wt, hemicellulose accounts for 20–35%wt and lignin for 14–26%wt [5]. Thermochemical processes such as pyrolysis and hydrothermal liquefaction allow the transformation of biomass into chemicals. Aqueous phases resulting from these processes contain acids, ketones and alcohols, including ethanol [6]. Ethanol is an attractive precursor for hydrogen production because it is safe to handle, easy to store and less toxic than methanol [7]. Steam reforming is the most studied among the different types of reforming. However, the high energy demand and unwanted secondary reactions have made aqueous phase reforming (APR) a growing alternative for hydrogen production. APR can be carried out using any bio-based compound soluble in water, and the most commonly used molecules are methanol [8–12], ethanol [13–23], ethylene glycol [24–32] and glycerol [33–42]. Oliveira et al. studied APR of maltose and malitol over PtPd/C catalyst and obtained H2 selectivity as high as 80% [43]. APR of different alcohols has also been investigated, such as the reforming of glycerol over Pt/C [44] or Pt-Fe/Al2O3 [45] and APR of methanol over NiMg-MMO [46]. Mao et al. studied APR of methanol over Pt/La2NiO4 and Pt-NiOx/LaCO3OH and obtained high catalyst stability [47]. Callison et al. found that reaction pathways of APR could be controlled using tailored Pt nanoparticles [40]. Further studies with platinum-based catalysts [48–51] have obtained high yields and selectivity towards H2 through APR. Molybdenum carbides have recently emerged as promising catalysts for H2 production [52]. Transition metal carbides have been studied as potential catalytic substitutes for noble metals [52]. Their structures consist in carbon atoms inserted into the lattices of transition metals [53]. Specifically, molybdenum carbides have shown similar catalytic activity to Pd or Pt [54] and good performance in biomass-derivatives conversion [55]. For example, Mo2C have been studied for the deoxygenation of acetic acid [56] and for ammonia synthesis [57]. Carbides have been investigated as a support for different metals (Pt, Ni, Cu, Fe, Co) for methanol steam reforming (MSR) [58–63], but also as an active phase whether in reforming reactions [64–66] or formic acid dehydrogenation [67], and recently as a promoter of another metal (Ni/Cu) [67]. Molybdenum carbides have shown to effectively produce H2 through methanol steam reforming [63,68]. Additionally, unsupported molybdenum carbides have been investigated for the decomposition of methanol and ethanol, obtaining high selectivity at elevated temperatures [69]. Two different active molybdenum carbides have been widely described, the α-MoC (fcc) phase and the β-Mo2C (hcp) phase. In regards to hydrogen production, the α-MoC has been reported to be much more active than the β-Mo2C [70]. Recently, Ni/α-MoC was evaluated for the aqueous phase reforming of methanol, and excellent activity and stability were reported (6 times higher than Pt/Al2O3), which was ascribed to a synergetic effect between atomically dispersed Ni and efficient O-H activation over α-MoC [12]. Moreover, as an active phase, β-Mo2C has been claimed to be active for formic acid reforming [65] and stable under aqueous and corrosive media [71]. However, some work has observed a loss of activity in MSR due to a phase transition from α-MoC to β-Mo2C [63]. On the other hand, zirconium oxide, ZrO2, is often used as a support because it can contribute to water dissociation in ethanol reforming to allow H2 generation in metal-support interface and provides additional adsorption sites [7]. ZrO2 presents several crystalline structures that have been reported to affect the catalytic activity of the active phase. For instance, hydrogen production by steam reforming of glycerol over Ni/ZrO2 has shown to be affected by the monoclinic phase content [72]. Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts have proven to be sulfur-resistant in methanation reaction [73], coke-resistant in methane reforming [74] and active for phenol hydrodeoxygenation [75]. In the present work, the production de hydrogen through APR of ethanol was evaluated on molybdenum carbides supported on zirconium and the effect of the type of the carbide crystalline phase as well as the effect of the type of ZrO2 were investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis Zirconium support was prepared by pH-controlled precipitation of ZrOCl2 (Merck, 97%) as described elsewhere [76]. Typically, a solution of ZrOCl2 at 0.4 M was prepared and slowly added under magnetic stirring at room temperature to another aqueous solution where the pH was adjusted with an ammonia solution (Supelco, 25%) and maintained constant during the precipitation. For the obtention of tetragonal phase, pH was maintained at 9 while at pH 10, the monoclinic phase was formed. The mixture was left for 1 h, the precipitate was filtered and washed with water and dried overnight at 80 ºC. The resulting powder was calcinated at 450 °C for 1 h with a 5 °C/min ramp. Catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation, in a nominal concentration of 10%wt Mo. (NH4)6Mo7O24 (Fluka, 99%) was dissolved in deionized water and then mixed with the support. The mixture was aged for 4 h at room temperature and then dried overnight at 100 °C. The catalysts were carburized using an adaptation of the method proposed by Volpe and Boudart [77]. For the obtention of the β crystalline phase, carburization was performed at 650 °C for 90 min (5 °C/min ramp) under 100 mL/min of a 75:25 mixture of H2:C2H4 (Indura). After carburization, catalysts were passivated at room temperature for 60 min under 75 mL/min of 5%O2/N2 (Indura). For the preparation of the α crystalline phase of the carbide, before the carburization step, the catalyst was treated with 40 mL/min of NH3 (Indura) at 650 °C for 2 h (5°/min ramp). The prepared catalysts are 10%Mo2C/m-ZrO2, 10%Mo2C/t-ZrO2, and 10%MoC/m-ZrO2, which will be referred to as 10BM, 10BT, and 10AT, respectively. The number 10 represents the metal loading of molybdenum, the first letter indicates the crystalline phase of the carbide (A for α and B for β), and the second letter corresponds to the crystalline phase of the zirconium support (M for monoclinic and T for tetragonal). 2.2 Characterization The catalysts were characterized by several techniques. N2 physisorption at −196 °C was used to determine textural properties such as surface area, pore size and pore volume. The analysis were carried out in a Micromeritics 3Flex instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), previously degassing the samples for 4 h at 350 °C with a SmartVac Prep Micromeritics device. The surface area was obtained using the BET method, pore volume was calculated from the total adsorbed quantity at P/P° = 0.99, and pore size distribution was determined with the BJH method using the desorption branch. XRD analysis was performed to evaluate structural properties in a Polycrystal X′Pert Pro PANalytical instrument with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.1541 nm) and equipped with a graphite monochromator. Bragg angles were scanned every 0.04° in the range 4°–100 ° for each sample. Chemical properties were determined by temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) using the same Micromeritics 3Flex device coupled with a Mass Spectrometer Cirrus 2 MKS Spectra. 5%H2/Ar was used as reducing gas, and CH4, CO2, CO, H2O effluents were measured using fragments 15, 44, 28, and 18, respectively. Finally, surface properties were studied by X-ray photoelectronic spectroscopy (XPS) in a SPECS spectrometer equipped with a FOCUS 500 monochromator and a Phoibos 150 hemispherical detector with Kα radiation (hν = 2984.3 eV). Spectra were calibrated in regards to the C1s region, adjusting the C–C peak to 284.8 eV. Deconvolution of the spectra was carried out using the XPSPEAK41 software with a combination of Lorentzian-Gaussian curve fitting. 2.3 Catalytic activity The catalysts were evaluated in a 20 mL batch reactor (Parr instrument) stirred at 645 rpm and heated at 250 °C under autogenous pressure reaching about 43 bar. Initially, the reactor was purged under inert gas (N2) and charged with 6 bar of N2 prior to heating. To remove the passivation layer, catalysts were reduced ex-situ prior to the reaction with 100 mL/min H2 (Indura) at 300 °C for 30 min, and rapidly transferred to the reactor with short exposure to air. The reactor was loaded with 40 mg of reduced catalyst and 15 mL of 0.4 M aqueous ethanol solution (Merck, HPLC gradient), then purged under N2 for 10 min. Once the desired temperature was reached, a 90 min timer was set, and afterwards the reactor was rapidly cooled to 100 °C. Then it was left to cool until room temperature, the final pressure was noted, and a sample of both gas and liquid (1.5 mL) were taken. Gas products were quantified by injecting 1 mL in a gas chromatograph (GC-2030, Shimadzu) equipped with a Carboxen 1010 PLOT column and TCD detector, using N2 as carrier gas. The gas distribution will be defined according to the molar fraction measured. Typically the injection temperature was set at 250ºC, and the column was heated during 25 min at 80 °C, with a carrier at 4 mL/min. Liquid products were analyzed with injection of 20 μL in an HPLC (eco, Shimadzu) equipped with a Zorbax Eclipse Plus C18 column and UV-Vis detector at 190 nm. The mobile phase was H2O, with a flowing rate of 0.8 mL/min. Furthermore, ethanol conversion was calculated using the following equation: C % = C etOH i − C etOH f C etOH i × 100 % Where C etOH i is the initial molar concentration of ethanol and C etOH f is the molar concentration of ethanol at the end of the reaction. 3 Results & discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Textural properties Textural properties of the bare supports and the resulting catalysts after carburization/passivation were obtained from N2-sorption isotherm and these are presented in Fig. 1. The corresponding surface areas, pore volumes and average pore diameter are given in Table 1. All isotherms can be classified as type IV, which is a characteristic of mesoporous solids such as zirconium oxide. m-ZrO2 support and catalyst show a type H1 hysteresis loop, indicating a cylindrical pore shape (Fig. 1a), whereas t-ZrO2 support and catalysts present a type H2 hysteresis loop, associated with bottle-neck pore geometry (Fig. 1b). These differences are merely due to the crystalline phase of the support, which also affects pore diameter distribution. Interestingly, 10BM has larger pores than the bare support, which could be associated with the carburization thermal treatment producing pore opening, as evidenced by the isotherm of the carburized bare support in Fig. 1a. In contrast, t-ZrO2 has a more similar pore diameter to its catalysts, suggesting that tetragonal zirconium oxide was stable during carburization. Pore volume values for 10BT are significantly lower than the bare support, therefore, it can be deduced that pore blockage occurred during impregnation/carburization in agreement with the pore size distribution (inserted graph in Fig. 1a). Ammonia treatment before carburization caused a slight expansion of the pores of 10AT. The average pore diameters found here are in good agreement with the ones published by Basahel et al. [78]. In every case, surface area and pore volume were greater for each support than for their corresponding catalysts (Table 1). Indeed, the addition of 10%wt of Mo should reduce at least about 10% the surface area as the surface area is generally given by the support. In the case of m-ZrO2, it was observed that the carburization was increasing the average pore diameter, resulting in a smaller surface area. The surface area displayed by 10BM is similar to the carburized m-ZrO2, therefore the loss of area in the case of 10BM can be ascribed to the modification of the textural properties during the carburization. On the contrary, in the case of t-ZrO2 the loss of surface observed for 10BT and 10AT is greater than the 10% expected, while the average pore diameter remains in the similar range. However, the pore volume was reduced suggesting that in the case of those catalysts, pore blocking occurs. 3.1.2 Structural properties XRD analysis showed characteristic diffraction peaks for monoclinic and tetragonal zirconium oxide ( Fig. 2). The small shoulder at 30° for m-ZrO2 corresponds to zirconium oxide on its tetragonal form, indicating the support is not pure monoclinic ZrO2 but a mixture containing a small amount of the tetragonal phase. The same can be said for t-ZrO2, where the two shoulders at 28° and 31° correspond to monoclinic ZrO2. Interestingly, catalysts present only diffraction peaks corresponding to their supports and none to molybdenum carbide. Even though it is possible that molybdenum peaks are hidden by zirconium in the case of the monoclinic phase (see patterns [79–81] in the figure). Another explanation is that the active phase is well-dispersed, with crystallite size below the detection limit of the technique. Furthermore, in the case of the tetragonal support, at an angle of 30°, a slight displacement of the diffraction peak of the support is observed after carburization. This shift is representative of slight distortion of the crystalline phase that might be caused by the treatment with ammonia, where some oxygen atoms might have been replaced by nitrogen. Indeed, the ionic radius of N is smaller than O’s [82], this replacement could have caused a contraction of the unit cell leading to displacement of the peak. On the other hand, it can be noticed that after the carburization the crystallite size seems slightly bigger eg: from 10 nm to 13 nm in the case of the monoclinic phase and from 6 to 7 and 10 nm for the tetragonal, 10BT and 10AT respectively according to the Scherrer equation. 3.1.3 Chemical properties The evolution of the MS signals related to the CH4, CO and CO2 production during from TPR experiments are presented in Fig. 3. According to the literature, methane can be formed when carbides react with hydrogen or by gasification of carbon species ca. graphitic, pyrolytic that might be formed during the carburization process, indeed the CH4 produced at around 460–490 °C, 600–690 °C, and 700–800 °C was related to carbidic, pyrolytic, and graphitic carbon, respectively [83]. However, carbide formation is complex and often oxycarbide formation is favored [84]. According to Fig. 3a, no CH4 signal is detected for 10BM, and therefore, no fully carburized were detected. On the contrary, three peaks corresponding to three types of carbides are observed for 10BT and 10AT. 10BT shows a strong predominance of the middle peak, which can be attributed to carbidic carbon [83] whereas 10AT has similar quantities of all three. It is worth mentioning that no methane related to graphitic or pyrolytic carbon was detected. The formation of CO during carburization of Mo is well-described. Previous studies state the carburization degree could be related to the area of CO formed during the TPR [85,86]. It is worth mentioning that more specifically, CO is obtained even when Mo is partially carburized (oxycarburized), for instance, in previous work it was observed that by increasing the carburization degree, the formation of CO was lower [85]. A small CO feature is detected for 10BM at 850 °C (Fig. 3b). 10BT shows two clear peaks at 750 °C and 950 °C, meaning there are two non-carburized species present. Finally, 10AT has a low intensity signal at 850 °C, indicating that this catalyst has an higher carburization degree than 10BT. Literature for CO2 formation during TPR is scarce. All three catalysts show CO2 signals during reduction (Fig. 3c). Previous work has proposed that the CO2 formation might be formed by oxycarbide reduction [87]. Thus, high oxycarbide presence is detected, particularly for 10BM and 10BT. 3.1.4 Surface properties Fig. 4 shows the XPS of Mo 3d, Zr 3d and O1s regions of the catalysts, and Table 2 summarizes the binding energies (B.E.) of the most intense Mo 3d 5/2 component of each doublet, their relative proportion and the surface Mo/Zr atomic ratios. Two doublets were identified in the Mo 3d region for 10BM catalyst (Fig. 4a): the Mo 3d 5/2 component of the most intense doublet is centered at 232.5 eV, and it was assigned to Mo+6 [88,89] corresponding to MoO3, whereas the second doublet less intense centered at 229.0 eV is in between Mo+2 and Mo+4 attributed to an oxycarbide Mo+δ species [85]. Note that no Mo2C is detected on the surface. For 10BT (Fig. 4b) three species were identified and assigned to an oxide Mo+6 (MoO3), an oxycarbide Mo+4 (MoOxCy) [90] and a carbide Mo+2 (Mo2C) [91]. The different oxycarbide species found for both catalysts could be explained by the crystalline phase of the support, which interacts with molybdenum during carburization. Mo/Zr atomic ratio for 10BT is four times higher than 10BM (Table 2), indicating a higher superficial distribution of the active phase on the support. In the Zr 3d region, the Zr+4 species was identified for 10BM (Fig. 4a) and assigned to ZrO2, as well as a sub-oxide species, whereas for 10BT (Fig. 4b), only ZrO2 was identified. This might explain the differences in carburized and non-carburized molybdenum species of both catalysts. XPS spectra for the Mo 3d region of 10AT catalyst shows three species present on the surface (Fig. 4c). The spectra looks highly similar to the previous two but it is shifted around 3 eV to higher binding energies. This could be explained by some electronic transfer from Mo to the support. Interestingly, the B.E. of Zr also shifted to higher values. Therefore some other species are “collecting” the electrons from both Mo and Zr. Indeed, as observed in Fig. 4 c, the peaks from the O1s region are shifted to lower B.E., suggesting there is an electronic density exchange between molybdenum and oxygen species, probably caused by oxygen vacancies [92]. Mo 3d doublets are attributed to Mo+6 (MoO3), Mo+4 (MoOxCy) and an oxynitride Mo+δ (MoOxNy) [93], the latter being formed during the ammonia treatment step before carburization. The Mo/Zr atomic ratio is 1.90 (Table 2), suggesting a higher relative superficial distribution of the active phase on the support than the other catalysts in this study. Two peaks were identified in the N1s region for 10AT at 396.7 and 398.2 eV and were assigned to the molybdenum oxynitride and zirconium nitride (not shown here), consistent with the Mo and Zr deconvolution. For all catalysts, a predominant C–C signal was identified for the C1s region, as well as O-CO for 10BM and C-O-C for 10BT and 10AT. No significant shifts were observed for C1s peaks. A summary of the characterizations can be seen in Fig. 5. All catalysts had partial pore blockage, and 10BM was less carburized than the others. Mo oxide and two types of Mo oxycarbide and Mo oxynitride were formed. 10BM had lower surface area and larger average pore diameter than the other samples. Catalysts supported on monoclinic zirconium formed mostly molybdenum oxide and oxycarbide, whereas the catalysts 10BT and 10AT formed molybdenum carbide as well as a different type of oxycarbide. The method of carburization had an effect on the species formed on the surface, with 10AT catalyst having molybdenum oxynitrides and ZrN after the ammonia treatment. 3.2 Catalytic properties 3.2.1 Activity and selectivity Ethanol conversion during APR and gas product distribution are shown in Fig. 6. The conversion of ethanol calculated at 90 min follows the order 10AT > 10BT > 10BM, which follows the same trend that was observed for relative superficial distribution of the active phases on the support obtained from XPS results. Nevertheless, the Mo/Zr measured over 10AT was about 7 times higher than 10BM but not the conversion, which suggests that the identity of the surface species might control the ethanol conversion rather than the surface distribution. The liquid phase was analyzed and as the liquids were presented in small quantities (accounting for less than 6% of carbon converted), the results were omitted here and the discussion will be focused on the gas phase. Regarding gas products, it was found that all catalysts produce hydrogen through APR of ethanol. However, 10BM provided 7 times more H2 than 10BT and 20 times more than 10AT catalyst. In other words, H2 selectivity follows the opposite order to catalyst conversion. XPS showed that 10BM had a type of oxycarbide on its surface that was not present on the other catalysts, which might be responsible for the enhanced H2 production. 10BT had the same type of oxycarbide as 10AT but in larger quantities, which helps the understanding of the differences in H2 selectivity. Moreover, 10BT and 10AT catalysts produced CH4, suggesting that the active site obtained over the tetragonal support was more selective toward methane production. TPR showed that these two catalysts had a type of carbide that was not obtained over the monoclinic support. Thus, the amount of H2 formed by APR over those catalysts was higher, but unfortunately it was consumed to form methane. Acetone production was also detected, which was previously reported over metal oxides with oxygen vacancies and amphoteric properties such as ZrO2 that are active in acetone production [94]. Typically, acetone can be obtained from ethanol by aldol condensation and/or dehydrogenation of acetaldehyde followed by ketonization [7]. Finally, methanol was also produced during APR in diluted quantities. To summarize, the highest activity was observed for the 10AT catalyst that was the only catalyst where some electronic density exchange between molybdenum and oxygen species could be detected probably caused by oxygen vacancies. On the contrary, the highest hydrogen production was obtained over 10BM that was the only catalyst that displayed Mo+δ species ascribed to oxycarbide phase. Finally, the tetragonal support might promote the formation of some carburized species that are more prominent to methane formation. The results obtained can be compared with some literature reports. The carbide catalysts obtained in the present work displayed a slightly lower hydrogen production at similar reaction conditions than the ones obtained by Pipitone et al. over 5% Pt/Al2O3 [48,49]. On the other hand, as expected, higher activity was obtained in the case of the α-MoC phase compared to the β-Mo2C [70], which is consistent with the literature. 3.2.2 Post-reaction catalyst characterization The best performing catalyst so far, 10BM, was further evaluated in a stability study and the spent catalyst was characterized by N2-physisorption, XRD and XPS. Textural and structural properties were compared to the fresh catalyst in Table 3 and Fig. 7, respectively. Table 3 and Fig. 7 showed that no significant changes were made to the textural and structural properties. The XPS results for the spent catalyst – named 10BMs – are shown in Fig. 8, and binding energies (B.E.) of the most intense Mo 3d 5/2 component of each doublet, their relative proportion and the surface Mo/Zr and Mo/C atomic ratios are summarized in Table 3. Two new species appear in the Mo 3d region apart from molybdenum oxide (Mo+6): Mo+2 assigned to Mo2C [17] and Mo+4 assigned to an oxycarbide [84]. This behavior indicates that the initial oxide or oxycarbides are partially reduced during the reaction. It is worth mentioning that the fresh catalyst presented two oxidized species ca. Mo+6 and Mo+δ, with a relative proportion of 57% and 43%, respectively (Table 3). Those relative proportions were reduced to 47% and 25% after the reaction. Interestingly the Mo+δ species was the most affected after the reaction, while the Mo+6 species decreased in a milder manner. Therefore, it can be proposed that during the reaction, Mo+6 species are mainly reduced to Mo+4 species, while Mo+δ species were reduced to Mo+2 species. On the other hand, it is relevant to note that the Mo 3d spectra for 10BMs (Fig. 8b) is slightly shifted to lower binding energies eg. 0.5–1 eV, whereas Zr 3d spectra moved to higher B.E. ca. 1.4–2.9 eV. This antagonist displacement suggests that an electronic density exchange is occurring between Mo and Zr, probably caused by more oxygen vacancies present in the spent catalyst, as has already been reported [95]. Further evidence of the increased oxygen vacancies is the additional zirconium sub-oxide that can be seen in the Zr 3d region for the spent catalyst [96,97]. Mo/Zr atomic ratio rises from 0.27 to 1.28, suggesting an increase in the distribution of active phases at the surface during the reaction. However, such behavior has been reported for carbides, as during the carburization step, graphitic carbon is formed and can cover the Mo active phase [98]. If, during the reaction, this graphitic carbon phase is reduced, the detectable amount of Mo would increase, causing the Mo/Zr atomic ratio to increase as well. Therefore, in the present case, the change in the Mo/Zr atomic ratio could also be attributed to the reduction of graphitic carbon. Furthermore, the Mo/C atomic ratio decreases from 1.96 to 0.67, indicating that the superficial carbon content is higher after reaction at the surface of the catalyst. This might be due to more organic compounds, such as ethanol or acetone, being deposited on the surface. Note that this phenomenon does not contradict previous hypotheses about graphitic carbon reduction because this could happen simultaneously with organic compound deposition during the reaction. Finally, the small signal in dark gray in the Mo 3d region corresponds to a contamination that can be dismissed because it represents less than 3% of total area. The stability of 10BM was studied over the course of five consecutive reactions without any treatment except reduction for 30 min at 300 °C prior to the reaction and the results are presented in Fig. 9. Ethanol conversion started at 37% and slowly decreased to 25%, indicating the catalyst is slightly less active after successive reactions. Regarding H2 production, after the first reaction the generated amount increased almost three times, to then progressively decrease. XPS results showed that the fresh catalyst had oxides and oxycarbides on its surface, whereas the spent catalyst also had carbides. Therefore, most likely oxycarbides are active for hydrogen production but not more so than carbides. Furthermore, XPS allowed to suspect an electronic density exchange between the active phase and the support of 10BMs, a phenomenon that could also be responsible for the enhanced H2 production. 4 Conclusions Molybdenum carbides over zirconium oxide were tested for hydrogen production through aqueous phase reforming of ethanol. Two crystalline phases were studied for molybdenum carbide (α and β) and for the support (monoclinic and tetragonal). Characterization showed mesoporous materials with surface areas between 39 and 58 m2/g, whose pores were cylindrical in the case of 10BM and bottle-neck shaped for 10BT and 10AT catalysts. XRD allowed confirming of crystalline phases of the supports and a high dispersion of active phases. TPR results showed oxide and oxycarbide presence for 10BM, but no molybdenum carbide. 10BT and 10AT catalysts showed all three species. XPS findings align with those of TPR and allowed the identification of oxynitrides in 10AT catalyst. Catalytic activity showed all catalysts are active in APR of ethanol. 10BT and 10AT catalysts achieved higher conversions than 10BM due to higher catalyst relative superficial distribution of active phases. 10BM catalyst produced far more H2, attributed to the oxycarbide on its surface. 10BT and 10AT also generated CH4, indicating the catalyst is reduced during the reaction. Post-reaction studies on 10BM revealed that the catalyst carburized during the reaction, which led to an enhanced H2 production. This catalyst is stable for at least five successive reactions. Finally, the best performing catalyst found in this work is 10BM or 10%Mo2C/m-ZrO2. CRediT authorship contribution statement César Pazo: Resources. coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum carbide catalysts supported on monoclinic and tetragonal zirconium oxide were studied for hydrogen production through aqueous phase reforming of ethanol. Catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, XRD, TPR and XPS. Results showed that 10%Mo2C/m-ZrO2 was less carburized and had a lower surface area than 10%Mo2C/t-ZrO2 and 10%MoC/t-ZrO2. Mo oxide was identified on the surface as well as two types of Mo oxycarbide and Mo oxynitride. The α crystalline phase of the carbide was more active than β phase and was ascribed to its higher relative superficial distribution. However, the α phase generated less H2 probably because there was less oxycarbide presence. 10%Mo2C/m-ZrO2 produced significantly more H2 and was stable for five consecutive reactions. This catalyst showed higher carburization degree after the reaction, which greatly enhanced the generation of H2, suggesting that carbides species improved H2 production compared to oxycarbides.
coredata.dc:title: H2 production through aqueous phase reforming of ethanol over molybdenum carbide catalysts supported on zirconium oxide.
